NAEB Network Programming
In general the WOSU staff has been enthusiastic about
the way program offerings nave developed. We approve of
the present trend toward more programs originating from
various universities to complement programs from non¬
university sources.
We suggest that most offerings from the Network be non¬
musical in nature and that whatever music is offered should
be of a nature not generally available on records. We believe
that many schools and departments of music have outstanding
faculty members or student groups capable of presenting this
special type of programming. This policy would limit quantity
but would provide a distinctive service.
Our staff would like to see more exchange of outstanding
talks or lectures available on the various campuses. By a
careful selective process we believe that it would be possible
to maintain a daily program of faculty talks which would not
only be authoritative but have wide listener appeal.
The Science fields are usually neglected and a cooperative
effort in developing one or more series in this field would be
welcome.
We wish to encourage more programs designed for youth,
including in-school broadcasts complete with teachers' manuals
and shows for out-of-school listening by junior and senior
high school students.
